title: How to Make Thread Spool Wine Corks

steps.headline: Consider the kind of wine bottle cork you'd like to create.
steps.description: You may want to design a cork that will match your or your gift recipient's décor so planning the color spool and thread is something to ponder.

steps.headline: Determine how many corks you'd like to create.
steps.description: Giving a set of four or six corks as a gift may be a nice display. Or if you are giving multiple gifts, take a count of the number of recipients before heading to the store.

steps.headline: Assess your thread needs.
steps.description: Thread comes in a variety of sizes, colors and textures. Examine your current supply and determine if you need to pick up new thread and whether your supply will meet your design needs.

steps.headline: Count your current cork supply.
steps.description: Either begin saving wine corks now survey your current collection. You want corks that are completely in tact with no missing pieces or stains. Typically recycled white wine corks work best (red wine corks may be stained).

steps.headline: Visit the craft store to pick up embroidery thread/string, wood glue and wooden spools.
steps.description: The thread and spools are the crowning design point so make sure you find thread and spools that are attractive. Find a sharp pair of scissors and double sided clear tape.

steps.headline: Tape one end of the thread to the lowest side of the wooden spool.
steps.description: Make sure the tape holds well as you will be using it as your anchor as you wind the thread around the spool.

steps.headline: Tightly wind the thread around the spool, covering it completely.
steps.description: You do not want to see any part of the wooden spool except for the top and bottom.

steps.headline: Place a decent amount of glue on the final end of the thread (once it has been completely covered) and hold in place.
steps.description: Run your thumb over the glue to make it translucent and allow it to dry.

steps.headline: Glue cork to the top of the cork.
steps.description: Carefully center the spool on top of the cork (wider side up) before adhering it with wood glue. Hold together for a few minutes until dry.

text: Design Your Corks Consider the kind of wine bottle cork you'd like to create. You may want to design a cork that will match your or your gift recipient's décor so planning the color spool and thread is something to ponder. Determine how many corks you'd like to create. Giving a set of four or six corks as a gift may be a nice display. Or if you are giving multiple gifts, take a count of the number of recipients before heading to the store. Assess your thread needs. Thread comes in a variety of sizes, colors and textures. Examine your current supply and determine if you need to pick up new thread and whether your supply will meet your design needs. Count your current cork supply. Either begin saving wine corks now survey your current collection. You want corks that are completely in tact with no missing pieces or stains. Typically recycled white wine corks work best (red wine corks may be stained). Visit the craft store to pick up embroidery thread/string, wood glue and wooden spools. The thread and spools are the crowning design point so make sure you find thread and spools that are attractive. Find a sharp pair of scissors and double sided clear tape. Create Thread Corks Tape one end of the thread to the lowest side of the wooden spool. Make sure the tape holds well as you will be using it as your anchor as you wind the thread around the spool. Tightly wind the thread around the spool, covering it completely. You do not want to see any part of the wooden spool except for the top and bottom. Place a decent amount of glue on the final end of the thread (once it has been completely covered) and hold in place. Run your thumb over the glue to make it translucent and allow it to dry. Glue cork to the top of the cork. Carefully center the spool on top of the cork (wider side up) before adhering it with wood glue. Hold together for a few minutes until dry.
